ms3 module¶

MuseScore3 Parser by Johannes Hentschel

class ms3.Score(file, score_features=[], separating_barlines=['double'])[source]¶

Bases: object

Parser for MuseScore3 MSCX files.

NOTE: Measure count mc refers to the mc th measure node, whereas measure number mn refers to the mn th measure in the score. The former is the number Bar displayed in the MuseScore status bar, minus 1 (MS starts counting at 1, the parser at 0). The latter can consist of several measure nodes and can be split across sections.

chord_series¶

If score_feature=[‘chords’], the chords are stored in this series with multiindex [‘mc’, ‘onset’]

Type

pandas.Series

dir¶

Directory where the parsed file is stored.

Type

str

file¶

Absolute or relative path to the MSCX file you want to parse.

Type

str

filename¶

Filename of the parsed file.

Type

str

info¶

Aggregation and strongly expanded version of the dataframes in mc_info. Useful for everyday work.

Type

obj:pandas.DataFrame

last_node¶

Measure count of the score’s last measure node.

Type

int

leftovers¶

Temporary container holding overflowing score_features during creation of sections.

Type

obj:pandas.DataFrame

mc_info¶

One DataFrame per staff where measure counts are index values and columns hold corresponding structural information. This information is best accessed in aggregated form in self.info.

Type

dict of pandas.DataFrame

measure_nodes¶

Keys of the first dict are staff IDs, keys of each inner dict are incremental measure counts (NOT measure numbers) and values are XML nodes.

Type

dict of dict of bs4.element.Tag

score¶

The complete XML structure of the parsed MSCX file.

Type

bs4.BeautifulSoup

score_features¶

Additional features you want to extract.

Type

list of {‘all’, ‘articulation’, ‘chords’, ‘clefs’, ‘dynamics’, ‘jumps’, ‘lyrics’, ‘texts’}

section_order¶

List of section IDs representing in which order the sections in section_structure are presented and repeated.

Type

list of int:

section_structure¶

Keys are section IDs, values are a tuple of two measure counts, the (inclusive) boundaries of the section. That is to say, no measure count can appear in two different value tuples since every measure can be part of only one section.

Type

list of tuple of int

sections¶

The sections of this score.

Type

dict of Section

separating_barlines¶

List of barline types that cause the score to be split in separate sections. Defaults to [‘double’].

Type

list of str

staff_nodes¶

Keys are staff IDs starting with 1, values are XML nodes.

Type

dict of bs4.element.Tag

super_sections¶

This dictionary has augmenting keys standing for one of the super_sections, i.e. sections that are grouped in the score by an englobing repetition, represented by lists of section IDs.

Type

dict of list

super_section_order¶

A more abstract version of section_order, using the keys from super_sections.

Type

list of int

get_notes(section=None, volta=None, volta_warning=True, multiindex=True, beatsize=None, merge_ties=False, propagate_chords=True, **kwargs)[source]¶

Retrieve list of notes as a DataFrame.

Parameters

  • section ((collection of) int) – Sections of which you want to see the notes. 0 = first, -1 = last (a, b) = sections from a to b; [a, b] = sections a and b Defaults to None which shows all sections. Repeating values in a collection leads to the corresponding note lists being repeated.

  • volta (int, optional) – Instead of section=’0b’ you can pass section=0, volta=2 or section=0, volta=-1 (if 2 is the last)

  • volta_warning (bool, optional) – If the requested section (e.g. section`=8) has voltas you need to specify which volta you want, e.g. using `section`=’8a’ or ‘8b’ or `section=8, volta=-1. It this is not specified, a warning thrown and the notes from the last volta are chosen. Set volta_warning to False to silence the warning and get the notes of all voltas.

  • multiindex (bool, optional) – Is True by default, in which case section numbers are displayed as the first level of a MultiIndex and a sequential index as the second. Pass multiindex=False to yield a note list with a single RangeIndex.

  • beatsize (bool or dict or fraction, optional) – Adds a column with a beat for every note. If True, the dict TIMESIG_BEAT is used to determine the beat size according to the time signature. By passing a dictionary you can overwrite or enhance the information in TIMESIG_BEAT. If you pass a fraction (such as ‘1/4’, 1/4, frac(1/4) or 0.25), this beat size is used for all time signatures.

  • merge_ties (bool, optional) – If False (by default), all tied notes represent individual events with ties given in column tied. Set to False to contract tied notes to single events (durations 1/2 _ 1/4 => 3/4)

  • propagate_chords (bool, optional) – If you want to see chords only for the places where they originally appear in the score instead of spreading them up to the next chord, pass False.

  • **kwargs – The following columns can be added by setting them to True: * octaves * note_names * beats (control beat size via beatsize, use beats for filtering) * pcs (pitch classes 0-11) * timesig (automatically shown if beats is shown) These and all other columns of the notelist can be filtered by passing feature=selector. The features are {‘n’, ‘mc’, ‘mn’, ‘onset’, ‘duration’, ‘gracenote’, ‘nominal_duration’, ‘scalar’, ‘tied’, ‘tpc’, ‘midi’, ‘staff’, ‘voice’, ‘volta’, ‘octaves’, ‘note_names’, ‘beats’} + self.score_features The selectors can be: * Single value: Only notes where feature equals selector. * 2-tuple (a,b): Slice where a <= feature <= b. * Collection: All notes where feature is in selector. * True yields all values that are not numpy.nan

Examples

S.get_notes() # all notes S.get_notes(0) # notes from the first section only S.get_notes(-1) # notes from the last section only S.get_notes((0,3)) # sections [0,1,2,3] S.get_notes((3,0)) # section [3,2,1,0] S.get_notes((-4,-1)) # fourth last to last section S.get_notes(None, False) # all notes with single RangeIndex S.get_notes(beatsize=True) # added column with beat sizes according to time signature S.get_notes(beatsize=1/4) # added column with every note’s quarter beat S.get_notes(note_names=True) # added column with note names S.get_notes(note_names=[‘A’, ‘D’, ‘G’]) # Only these notenames S.get_notes(octaves=True) # added column with notes’ octaves S.get_notes(octaves=(6,10)) # Only notes in octaves 6 through 10 S.get_notes(pcs=True) # added column with (MIDI) pitch classes S.get_notes(pcs=[1,3,6,8,10]) # only black keys on the piano S.get_notes(mn=1) # all notes with measure number 1 S.get_notes(duration=[0.5, 1]) # all notes with duration of a half or a whole note S.get_notes(duration=(0.5, 1)) # all notes with duration of a half, a whole, or in between S.get_notes(n=(0,5)) # get first 5 notes from every section

get_section(section=None, volta=None, volta_warning=True, propagate_chords=True)[source]¶
Parameters

  • section ((collection of) int) – Sections of which you want to see the notes. 0 = first, -1 = last (a, b) = sections from a to b; [a, b] = sections a and b Defaults to None which shows all sections. Repeating values in a collection leads to the corresponding note lists being repeated.

  • volta (int, optional) – Instead of section=’0b’ you can pass section=0, volta=2 or section=0, volta=-1 (if 2 is the last)

  • volta_warning (bool, optional) – If the requested section (e.g. section`=8) has voltas you need to specify which volta you want, e.g. using `section`=’8a’ or ‘8b’ or `section=8, volta=-1. It this is not specified, a warning thrown and the notes from the last volta are chosen. Set volta_warning to False to silence the warning and get the notes of all voltas.

  • propagate_chords (bool, optional) – If you want to see chords only for the places where they originally appear in the score instead of spreading them up to the next chord, pass False.

itersections(section=None, repeats=True, volta=None, multiindex=False)[source]¶

Iterate through sections’ note lists.

Parameters

  • section (int, optional) – Pass a section index if you want to iterate through all its repetitions with correct voltas being taken care of. By default, iterate through all sections.

  • repeats (bool, optional) – Defaults to True. If you don’t want to iterate through the different repeats, pass False and define the parameter volta (if the piece has any).

  • volta (int, optional) – If you pass an integer, at every repeat the same volta is included. Pass -1 to always use the last volta. Defaults to automatic behaviour.

  • multiindex (bool, optional) – Defaults to False. Pass True if you want a 2-level multiindex where the first level has the section number (1a for first repeat, 1b for second etc.)

Returns

At every iteration, a DataFrame with a list of notes is returned.

Return type

generator

class ms3.Section(parent, first_mc, last_mc, index, repeated, start_break, end_break, voltas=[])[source]¶

Bases: object

Holds the properties of a section.

first_mc, last_mc

Measure counts of the section’s first and last measure nodes.

Type

first_mn, last_mn

First and last measure number as shown in the score.

Type

int

start_break, end_break

What causes the section breaks at either side.

Type

str

index¶

Index (running number) of this section.

Type

int

notes¶

DataFrame holding all notes and their features.

Type

pandas.DataFrame

parent¶

The parent Score object that is creating this section.

Type

Score

previous_section, next_section

Indices of the previous and following sections in the score.

Type

int

repeated¶

Whether or not this section is repeated.

Type

bool

subsection_of¶

If section is a subsection, the index of the super_section, None otherwise.

Type

int

voltas¶

Ranges of voltas. Default: empty list

Type

list of range

class ms3.SliceMaker[source]¶

Bases: object

This class serves for passing slice notation such as :3 as function arguments. .. rubric:: Example

SL = SliceMaker() some_function( slice_this, SL[3:8] )

ms3.a_n_range(c, n)[source]¶

Generates character a and the n-1 following characters. :param c: Start character. :type c: char :param n: Number of total characters. :type n: int

Example

>>> list(a_n_range('b', 4))
['b', 'c', 'd', 'e']

ms3.chord_propagation(df, chord_series)[source]¶

ms3.compute_mn(df, check=True)[source]¶
Df with first column for excluded measures and facultative second column

for offset (“add to bar count”); measure counts in the index.

Example

>>> df
        dont_count      numbering_offset
0       NaN             NaN
1       1               NaN
2       NaN             NaN
3       NaN             -1
4       NaN             NaN
>>> compute_mn(df)
0    1
1    1
2    2
3    2
4    3
ms3.compute_repeat_structure(mc_repeats_volta)[source]¶
Parameters

df (pandas.DataFrame) – Needs to have the two columns [‘repeats’, ‘volta’] where for every measure count in the index a tag {‘startRepeat’, ‘endRepeat’, ‘firstMeasure’, ‘lastMeasure’} and/or a volta number (typically {1, 2, 3}) is given.

Returns

Beginning and ending measure counts of repeated sections.

Return type

list of tuple of int

Example

>>> df
        repeats         volta
0       firstMeasure     NaN
16      NaN                 1
17      endRepeat           1
18      NaN                 2
19      startRepeat         NaN
23      endRepeat           1
24      endRepeat           2
25      NaN                 3
31      startRepeat         NaN
39      endRepeat           1
40      NaN                 2
>>> compute_repeat_structure(df)
[(0, 18), (19, 25), (31, 40)]
ms3.convert_timesig(tag)[source]¶

Turns a TimeSig-tag into a fraction. If you pass a list of tags, all need to represent the same time signature. In case of errors, None is returned.

Parameters

tag (bs4.element.Tag (or list)) –

Returns

Return type

fractions.Fraction

ms3.feature_from_node(tag, nodes)[source]¶

Gets a tag name and a list of corresponding tags and computes a useful value from it.

Parameters

  • nodes (list of bs4.element.Tag (or list)) – Tags from which to extract values.

ms3.get_volta_structure(df)[source]¶
Parameters

df (pandas.DataFrame) – Needs to have the two columns [‘repeats’, ‘volta’] where for every measure count in the index a tag {‘startRepeat’, ‘endRepeat’, ‘firstMeasure’, ‘lastMeasure’} and/or a volta number (typically {1, 2, 3}) is given.

Returns

For every volta group, one list of integers per volta containing the measure counts that this volta spans.

Return type

list of list of list of int

ms3.merge_tied_notes(df)[source]¶

In a note list, merge tied notes to single events with accumulated durations. Input dataframe needs columns [‘duration’, ‘tied’, ‘midi’, ‘staff’, ‘voice’]

ms3.search_in_list_of_tuples(L, pos, search, add=0)[source]¶

Returns a list of indices for tuples that contain search at position pos.

Parameters

  • L (list of tuple) – List of tuples in which you want elements with value search.

  • pos (int) – In which position of the tuples to search.

  • search (object) – What to look for.

  • add (int, opt) – How much you want to add to each returned index value.

ms3.sort_dict(D)[source]¶

Returns a new dictionary with sorted keys.

ms3.tpc2degree(tpc, major=True)[source]¶

Return scale degree of a tonal pitch class where 0 = I, -1 = IV, -2 = bVII, 1 = V etc.

ms3.tpc2key(tpc)[source]¶

Return the name of a key signature, e.g. 0 = C/a, -1 = F/d, 6 = F#/d# etc.

ms3.tpc2name(tpc)[source]¶

Return name of a tonal pitch class where 0 = C, -1 = F, -2 = Bb, 1 = G etc.

ms3.tpc2pc(tpc)[source]¶

Turn a tonal pitch class into a MIDI pitch class

ms3.transpose_to_C(note_list, measure_list=None)[source]¶

Either note_list needs column keysig or you need to pass measure_list with keysig
